description: From Middle English tablet, from Old French tablete (Modern French tablette), diminutive of table (“table”).

entries.meaning: A slab of clay, stone or wood used for inscription.
(religion) A short scripture written by the founders of the Bahá'í faith.
A pill; a small, easily swallowed portion of a substance.
examples: Many people take vitamin tablets as a food supplement.

entries.meaning: A block of several sheets of blank paper that are bound together at the top; pad of paper.
(computing) A tablet computer, a type of portable computer.
(Scotland) A confection made from sugar, condensed milk and butter, produced in flat slabs, with a grainer texture than fudge.
(rail transport) A type of round token giving authority for a train to proceed over a single-track line.

verbs.description: tablet (third-person singular simple present tablets, present participle tableting or tabletting, simple past and past participle tableted or tabletted)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To form (a drug, etc.) into tablets.
